projectDesc.p: To the tune “Note after Note, Long Song”—"Looking and Searching" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the tune “Note after Note, Long Song”—"Looking and Searching"
Looking and searching, looking and searching,
cold and quiet, cold and quiet,
lonesome, dismayed, and desolate; lonesome, dismayed, and desolate.
At the time when it has just turned warm yet is still quite cold,
it is the hardest for one to rest.
How can two or three cups of weak wine
shield one from
the harsh wind in the evening?
The wild geese have flown past;
what truly pains the heart,
is that I knew them from the past.
Yellow flowers pile all over the ground,
withered and wilted.
Now who would pluck them?
I guard the window;
how do I endure this darkness by myself?
The parasol tree in the slight rain
at dusk,
dripping and drizzling, dripping and drizzling.
In such circumstances,
how could the single word “sorrow” suffice?
